title: Did Bill Gates save Apple? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you aren’t old enough, you might only know Apple as the hugely successful maker of iPhones, iPods, iPads, exciting new Macintosh computers, services like iCloud and iTunes, and thriving retail stores. But if you are old enough, you’ll remember the dark times when Apple computer was close to bankruptcy. This was memorably captured in June of 1997 when Wired magazine ran this famous cover story: 101 Ways to Save Apple  And years later, this article was discussed quite often after Apple was returned to success - Here were some of the crazy ideas floated to keep Apple from going out of business in 1997 A number of factors rescued Apple. Steve Job returned to Apple through the acquisition of Next computer, new products were introduced like a new generation of Macintoshes, products were modernized. But one critical factor was Microsoft stepped in and invested $150M to rescue Apple (or at least Apple’s stock). Microsoft also committed to continue publishing Microsoft office for the Macintosh computers. This has also been covered in many articles like August 6, 1997 -- The day Apple and Microsoft made peace. The agreement with Microsoft may have come at a time of great desperation for Apple, but it worked out quite well for the company. The investment was a stock purchase, and didn't directly put money into the hands of Apple. But, it did act to stablilize Apple's stock. At the time, the company's stock was trading at 86 cents a share adjusted for dividends and the three splits since then. It truly took off in 1999, once it became clear that Apple was truly back. More importantly, perhaps, was Gates' promise to continue delivering Microsoft Office products for the Mac going forward. Along with the stock, Apple's financial position soon stabilized, with the original iMac arriving the following year as Apple's most successful new product in years. And, any betrayal that Apple partisans felt about the embrace of Bill Gates failed to have any lingering effects. Why did Microsoft do this? Well, Microsoft was in the middle of antitrust investigation by the US government, and if Apple had failed, it would have made Microsoft’s monopoly position more negative. Microsoft also had a great business selling software for Macintoshes, so perhaps Microsoft saw this as a way to preserve that market. Whatever the case, Microsoft helped keep Apple alive until they could get their new products ready. Macworld Boston 1997-The Microsoft Deal  And:

Did Bill Gates save Apple? Here’s the story as I remember it. Jobs left Apple in May of 1985 after a the Board of Directors removed him from Chairman of the Board. With NeXt and Pixar in his pocket he returned in 1997 as interim CEO. Apple was on its’ last legs, close to running out of cash. So Steve called Bill Gates and they had a discussion that revolved around the possibility that if Apple went out of business, Microsoft might well be at risk to be investigated as a monopoly. As I understand it, Gates/Microsoft wrote Apple a LARGE check to ensure that Apple would remain in business. And with Steve back leading Apple’s product design and development, the rest is history. I assume that Microsoft ended up with Stock so that proved to be a very smart investment!!!

No. Apple saved Apple. Microsoft provided breathing room (by providing IE and MS Office for the next 5 years on the Mac platform) for Apple to clean up their problems. MS had enough of their own problems with the DOJ at the time and could only benefit from Apple surviving in the PC market space as another viable competitor.

He did promise to keep making a version of ms office for the Mac. I’ve seen the Steve job speech where they conference with Bill. If he hadn’t millions of casual users wouldn’t be using a Mac and it would have remained a niche product for creative types. This may or may not have been enough for them to survive. Apple has had their backs to the wall a few times.
